text:
Great read. Too often many programmers get intrigued with trying to learn multiple languages due to hype or tutorial hell. They miss the big picture, choosing the right tool for the job. 

I think your blogpost is good and would be more solid if you were to add the main applications and frameworks available in each language (e.g. python devops + ml, scala for spark, javascript for nodejs backend + frontend) as library maturity IMO is as big of a deciding factor in choosing a language as the language itself.

IMO Julia would be the perfect lang for my day to day data science work if it werent for 2 problems.
1. Being the only one at work who knows julia.
2. Compiling Julia into portable binaries is too slow, inefficient, and weird.

Hopefully these both get better in the future. But for now python seems like the best language for ML-DS-ops.

Anyways great work :raised_hands:

Yea I know exactly where you are coming from, I think you're right. It would benefit from a discussion of ecosystem maturity and Ops. I agree also compiling Julia takes a long time, sometimes on the order of a half hour. That's a serious penalty if you have a bug...

A more day-to-day DS would disagree with my selection. I am in a weird spot. I should include those kinds of considerations to connect with people doing more or less the industry standard. Not too long ago I was a DS.

text:
Great points. For Lisp I was referring to CLisp - but agreed that needs to change! Good call on Clojure. I was referring to matlab for datascience, but you're right there are probably millions of matlab users!

I consider python to support functional programming paradigms. Is it a FP language? I don't think so - but maybe someone smarter than me could talk me through it. My reasoning is - the language doesn't seem to benefit from using FP syntax? Its more like an artifact of making everything an object. Which is a weird idea. Arguably python isn't an OOP either... Its just kind of a thing...

So Perl and Ruby can be compiled to something like byte code, but I agree I should get rid of that - they aren't truly compiled languages.

Mentioning Excel as a programming language is a misnomer. I try not to be a tool snob I really do, but Excel is like a buisiness intelligence tool more than anything else. Don't mention VBA I'll feel sick lol.

text: Excel puts mountains of data humans cannot understand in your face and asks you to hide your code. Meanwhile most people who work with data have decided - to show the code and hide the data for good reason :smile:.  Also excel cannot open a majority of data sets I work on, period. I get that people use it, and it works for them, but it's filled with bad practices for its primary use case. IE, users can hide sheets/columns then go pass a spread sheet along lol. Imagine hiding code in a project and sharing it with your team :ahhhhhhh:
